nodes.whoTheyAre: Kevin J. Krizek has been examining the environmental, social and health impacts of our urban transportation choices for twenty-five years.
nodes.whyListen:
Through his work both domestic and international, Kevin J. Krizek's developed informed insights into solving one of the world's most pressing problems -- how to reverse the automobile-focused nature of our environments, sharing remedies across borders that are both aspirational and evidence-based.

He has authored or edited several books: Advanced Introduction to Urban Transport Planning, Metropolitan Transport and Land Use and End of Traffic and the Future of Access. He earned a PhD in Urban Design and Planning and MSCE from the University of Washington in Seattle. His master’s degree in regional planning is from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and his undergraduate degree in engineering was awarded by Northwestern University.

He was the scientific director for the Velo-city 2017 research symposium in the Netherlands -- held as part of the world’s largest conference on bicycling. Beginning in September 2021, he will serve as a senior advisor in Washington DC to the Under Secretary of the Environment, Energy and Equity as part of a US Department of State Jefferson Fellowship.

videoData.description: The pandemic spurred an unprecedented reclamation of urban space, ushering in a seemingly bygone era of pedestrian pastimes, as cars were sidelined in favor of citizens. Highlighting examples from across the United States, environmental designer Kevin J. Krizek reflects on how temporary shifts -- like transforming streets into places for dining, recreation and community -- can become permanent fixtures that make for more livable and sustainable cities.

footnotes.annotation:
> “Now, one third of all the land in cities is set up for cars.”

In some U.S. cities, [like Phoenix, Arizona](https://par.nsf.gov/servlets/purl/10200589), parking lots take up [one-third of all land area](https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/08/arts/design/taking-parking-lots-seriously-as-public-spaces.html).

> “It propelled my colleague and me to start studying these changes in 55 of the largest cities in the U.S.”

For more information about this study, [see here](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X21000214).

> “Shortly after the lockdown, the city unfurled a 30 page playbook to use their street space better.”

For more information about Seattle’s Stay Healthy Streets program, [see here](https://www.seattle.gov/transportation/projects-and-programs/programs/stay-healthy-streets).

> “These types of modes, they can serve mostly the same purpose as cars, trucks, SUVs, but they do so using a third of the space to get around.” 

While variation could depend on factors [like the speed](https://www.elsevier.com/books/sustainable-transport/tolley/978-1-85573-614-6) at which the vehicles are traveling, bicycles and small vehicles could [take up less than a third](http://vehicleforasmallplanet.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/TPR.pdf) of the space to get around than standard vehicles.

> “And what we're seeing is that they're redesigning 50 miles of streets over the next two years to bring in more welcoming environments for bike plus type vehicles.”

According to Pittsburgh's Bike(+) Plan, [more than 50 miles of bike friendly facilities](https://apps.pittsburghpa.gov/redtail/images/9907_Pittsburgh_Bike+_Plan_DRAFT_06_09_2020.pdf) have already been added.

> “Further, the Bike(+) Plan is helping the city reduce transportation related emissions 50 percent by 2030 all while expanding affordable access to jobs and destinations.”

For more information, [see here](https://pittsburghpa.gov/domi/bikeplan).

> “More than half of all car trips in urban and suburban areas are less than four miles.”

For more details, [see here](https://nhts.ornl.gov/vehicle-trips).

> “Now we didn't need a pandemic or 80 percent reduction in our local economies …”

According to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, [more than 82 percent](https://www.uschamber.com/series/above-the-fold/latest-job-market-data-shows-the-uneven-impacts-of-k-shaped-recovery-us) of the jobs lost between February and September 2020 were service jobs.

> “The number of people who die in car crashes is equal to a Boeing 737 going down every other day.”

According to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, there were [36,096 motor vehicle traffic fatalities](https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/813004) in 2019. This amounts to almost 200 fatalities every other day, which is about the number of passengers that [a typical Boeing 737 can accommodate](https://www.faa.gov/news/updates/?newsId=93206).
